data.title: Le Corbeau (1943)

data.text:
★★★★☆

This was the film that almost did for Henri-Georges Clouzot’s career. The French director, best known for The Wages of Fear and Diabolique, was condemned for making it during the Nazi occupation with a German-controlled production company. It didn’t help that the story was deemed by some to demonise the French people.

It’s certainly not a rosy portrait of provincial France, being a pitch-black account of how a series of mysterious letters, written by “the Raven” (le Corbeau), whip up “a whirlwind of hate and calumny” in an unnamed town. A suave local doctor (Pierre Fresnay) is accused of being a “cheat, liar, thief and abortionist”; suicide and murder follow. It’s part whodunnit, part film noir, with Pierre Larquey’s psychiatrist getting the best
